description: Items are "dropped" blocks or items (non-block resources) that appear in the world, rather than being in the inventory of the player or a tile entity; they are a type of entity.
Drops are items that appear when mobs and some other entities die or when most kinds of blocks are broken.

The player is the character who can be controlled in Minecraft. The two default player skins are known as Steve (a name suggested by Notch as a joke[1] but later confirmed in the "change skin" menu on minecraft.net and in-game as the default name in Bedrock Edition) and Alex, with all unchanged skins being split between the two default skins.

The inventory is the pop-up menu that the player uses to manage items they carry. From this screen a player can equip armor, craft items on a 2×2 grid, and equip tools, blocks, and items. The player's skin is also displayed here.
An item frame is an entity‌[JE  only] or block entity‌[BE  only] that displays the item or block that is inside it.
Blocks are the basic units of structure in Minecraft that can be directly placed in the game world.
Entities encompass all dynamic, moving objects throughout the Minecraft world.
A boat is both an item and a vehicle entity.

A bed is a block that allows a player to sleep and to reset their spawn point to within a few blocks of the bed in the Overworld. If the bed is obstructed, the player spawns at the default world spawning location.
The heads-up display (HUD) appears on screen while the player is in the game. It is superimposed on their view of the game world.

Boots are a type of armor that covers the feet of the player. There are six types of boots: leather boots, chainmail boots, iron boots, diamond boots, gold boots and netherite boots‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].
Chestplates are a type of armor that covers the upper body of the player. There are six types of chestplates: leather, chainmail, iron, diamond, gold and netherite‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].

Helmets are a type of armor that covers the head of the player. There are seven types of helmets: leather cap, chainmail helmet, iron helmet, diamond helmet, gold helmet, netherite helmet‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16], and turtle shell.

Leggings are a type of armor that covers the lower body of the player. There are six types of leggings: leather pants, chain leggings, iron leggings, diamond leggings, gold leggings and netherite leggings‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].
Coal is an item mainly obtained by harvesting coal ore blocks. It is used as fuel, for crafting torches, or for trading with villagers.
Chorus fruit is a food item that can be eaten, or cooked into popped chorus fruit.

Banner patterns are items used to customize banners inside looms.
There are 6‌[upcoming: JE 1.16] patterns in Java Edition and 6 in Bedrock Edition.
Clocks are items that display the current in-game time by displaying the sun and the moon's position relative to the horizon.
Compasses are an item used to point to the world spawn. They are crafted using 4 iron ingots and one piece of redstone dust.
The trading system is a gameplay mechanic that allows players to trade emeralds for items (and vice-versa) with villagers and wandering traders.
Brewing is the process of creating potions, splash potions and lingering potions by adding various ingredients to water bottles in a brewing stand.

Crafting is how the player makes many items and blocks in Minecraft. To craft something, a player moves items from their inventory to a crafting grid, arranging them according to a recipe. A 2×2 crafting grid can be accessed from the player's inventory and a 3×3 grid can be accessed by using a crafting table.

Banner patterns are items used to customize banners inside looms.
There are 6‌[upcoming: JE 1.16] patterns in Java Edition and 6 in Bedrock Edition.
Blaze powder is an item made from a blaze rod obtained from blazes. Its main uses are to fuel brewing stands, to brew strength potions, and to make eyes of ender to take the player to the End.
Blaze rods are items obtained from blazes. They are needed to brew potions, as they are needed to make a brewing stand, to brew the potions, and blaze powder to fuel it.
Books are items used in enchanting.
Brick is an item used to craft brick blocks and flower pots.
Clay[a] is the item obtained from clay blocks used for crafting or making bricks.
Diamonds are a rare mineral obtained from diamond ore or loot chests. They are mainly used to craft high-tier tools and armor, and the enchantment table.
The dragon's breath is a brewing item that is used solely to make lingering potions.
Emeralds are an uncommon mineral, and are used in trading or to power beacons.
Feathers are items dropped by chickens and parrots, as well as tamed cats as morning gifts.
A fermented spider eye is a brewing ingredient.
Firework stars are items used to determine the color, effect, and shape of firework rockets.
Flint is a mineral obtained from gravel.
A glistering melon slice[a] is a non-edible item used for brewing potions of healing. It is also one of the many potion ingredients that can be used to make mundane potions.
Glowstone dust is an item used to craft glowstone, create thick potions, and create potions with increased strength and decreased duration.
Gold ingots are metal ingots used to craft various items and used as currency for bartering with piglins.
A gold nugget is an item used to make gold ingots and other various golden items.
Ghast tears are brewing items dropped by ghasts.
Gunpowder is an item that is used for explosion-related recipes.
A heart of the sea is a rare item that can be crafted into a conduit.
A honey bottle is a consumable drink item obtainable by using a glass bottle on a beehive or a bee nest.
Honeycombs are items obtained from bee nests and beehives.
Leather is an animal skin used to make armor and books.
Magma cream is an item used in brewing to create potions of Fire Resistance, and to build magma blocks.
A nautilus shell is an item that is used for crafting conduits.
A nether brick is an item made by smelting netherrack in a furnace.
Nether quartz is a smooth, white mineral found in the Nether.
The nether star is a rare item dropped by the wither that is used solely to craft beacons.
Netherite ingots are crafting materials used to make the strongest-tier tools, weapons, and armor. Unlike other items, they are not destroyed when thrown into fire or lava.
Netherite scrap is a material smelted from ancient debris, which is found in the Nether. Its sole use is for crafting netherite ingots.
Paper is an item crafted from sugar cane.
Phantom membranes are leathery animal skins obtained from killing phantoms.
Popped chorus fruit is an item obtained by smelting chorus fruit, and used to craft end rods and purpur blocks. Unlike raw chorus fruit, the popped fruit is inedible.
Prismarine crystals are crystals used to craft sea lanterns.
Prismarine shards are items obtained by defeating guardians or elder guardians.
Rabbit hide is an item dropped by rabbits.
A rabbit's foot is a brewing item obtained from rabbits.

Shulker shells are items dropped by shulkers that are used solely to craft shulker boxes.
A slimeball is an item commonly dropped by slimes.
A stick is an item used for crafting many tools and items.
A portfolio is an item that can save photos taken with a camera.[1]
The camera is an entity that is capable of capturing and storing images. In Education Edition, it works together with the portfolio item to create collections of pictures.[1]

Creative mode is one of the main game modes in Minecraft. Creative mode strips away the survival aspects of Minecraft and allows players to easily create and destroy structures and mechanisms. It also changes the background music.
Gives an item to one or more players.
Commands are advanced features activated by typing certain strings of text.
Markus Alexej Persson, more commonly known as Notch, is the creator of Minecraft and one of the founders of Mojang AB.

Block models are used to depict all the blocks in the game, whereas item models are used to display the items in the players hand, on their head (helmets and hats), on the ground, in the inventory, in item frames and on armor stands. As there are different variants of some blocks, block states are used to link these with the corresponding models. Each model and each block state has its own file, which is of the .json format. Even the icons used in the inventory are defined in these files.
Item repair is a feature that allows players to repair damaged tools, armor, or other items with durability by combining them in the crafting grid or a grindstone.

Item durability is a property that affects all tools, weapons, and armor, as well as certain other usable items. It represents the number of useful actions an item can perform and depletes upon item use. The bar starts at green, but as the durability decreases, the color turns to red. When the durability is empty, the item is about to become destroyed. Durability may be increased by merging two damaged items or repairing them with materials in an anvil, or through the mending enchantment.
An item is an object that exist only within the player's inventory and hands, or displayed in item frames.

Smelting is a method of producing refined goods. It has the same idea as crafting: a player supplies acceptable ingredients, and receives a corresponding output. However, smelting utilizes furnaces, blast furnaces, or smokers, which have a unique interface: one input field for the object to be heated, a secondary input field for the fuel, and one output field for the final smelted product. For example, two saplings (fuel) could be used to smelt one wood (input) into one charcoal (output). Raw food items can also be smelted using a campfire, while smokers and blast furnaces can smelt certain types of items twice as fast as usual at the cost of being completely unable to smelt any other items.

Enchanting is a mechanic that augments armor, tools, weapons, and books with one or more of a variety of "enchantments" that improve an item's existing abilities or imbue them with additional abilities and uses.

Mobs are "living", moving game entities. The term "mob" is short for "mobile".[1]
Mobs also can be attacked and hurt (from falling, burning, attacked by player or mob, falling into the void, etc) and some of them can be drowned. Mobs like cod, salmon, tropical fish, pufferfish, drowned, guardian, elder guardian can't be drowned, mobs also have a different AI for some mobs. And when killed, some mobs can drop a different loots.
A redstone circuit is a structure that activates or controls mechanisms.

Helmets are a type of armor that covers the head of the player. There are seven types of helmets: leather cap, chainmail helmet, iron helmet, diamond helmet, gold helmet, netherite helmet‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16], and turtle shell.
Chestplates are a type of armor that covers the upper body of the player. There are six types of chestplates: leather, chainmail, iron, diamond, gold and netherite‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].

Speed is a status effect that increases an entity's walking speed by 20% multiplied by the effect level.  It expands a player's field of view (FOV) accordingly.  Negative levels decrease speed.
Slowness decreases walking speed.
Jump Boost is a status effect that temporarily increases the jump height of the player.
Instant Health is a instant status effect that increases health for living mobs and damages the undead.
Instant Damage is a instant status effect that decreases health for living mobs and heals the undead.
Poison inflicts damage over time, reducing the player's health to , but cannot kill. In Bedrock Edition, there is a separate effect in addition to this one, also called Poison, which can kill.

Water breathing is a status effect that prevents or delays drowning, and allows waterlogged beds‌[Bedrock Edition only] to be used. It also prevents or delays squid, salmon, cod, pufferfish, and tropical fish from taking suffocation damage from being on land.‌[Bedrock Edition only][verify]
Fire Resistance nullifies most fire-based damage. Fire Resistance is a status effect that does not change its power as its potency changes.
Night Vision is a status effect that primarily enhances the player's ability to see in darkness. It allows the player to see clearly underwater as well.
Invisibility is a status effect that turns entities invisible. The effect does not change its power as its potency changes.
Strength is a status effect which increases attack power.
Weakness decreases attack power.
Regeneration is a status effect which increases a player's (or mob's) health over time and causes the health bar to jitter.
Resistance reduces most damage.
Slow Falling is a status effect that causes the affected mob to fall slower and take no fall damage, but does not prevent ender pearl damage.
Elements and isotopes are blocks which serve as an essential part of chemistry in Minecraft.
Nausea warps and wobbles the player's vision similarly to a nether portal.
Blindness is a status effect that impairs the player's vision.
Blazes are flying hostile mobs found in nether fortresses.

The inventory is the pop-up menu that the player uses to manage items they carry. From this screen a player can equip armor, craft items on a 2×2 grid, and equip tools, blocks, and items. The player's skin is also displayed here.
Swamp huts are generated structures that have the ability to spawn witches and (upon generation) one black cat.

Status effects are various conditions, which can be either helpful or harmful, that affect an entity. They can be inflicted in various ways throughout the game, including consuming potions and some food items, being in the range of beacons and conduits, and being attacked by or close to certain mobs.
A glistering melon slice[a] is a non-edible item used for brewing potions of healing. It is also one of the many potion ingredients that can be used to make mundane potions.
Ghast tears are brewing items dropped by ghasts.
A spider eye is a poisonous food and brewing item.
Blaze powder is an item made from a blaze rod obtained from blazes. Its main uses are to fuel brewing stands, to brew strength potions, and to make eyes of ender to take the player to the End.
Potions are bottled substances. Most of them are brewable items, many of which give the consumer a time-limited effect when drank.
A hopper is a block that can be used to catch item entities, or to transfer items into and out of containers.
Redstone dust[a] is a mineral that can transmit redstone power when placed as a block.

Undead mobs are a category of mobs that share certain traits: they are healed by potions of Harming and harmed by potions of Healing, withers do not attack them, and they are immune to the Poison and Regeneration effects. Undead mobs also take extra damage from weapons enchanted with Smite.
Healing is the mechanic of regaining lost health.
Instant Damage is a instant status effect that decreases health for living mobs and heals the undead.
Commands are advanced features activated by typing certain strings of text.
Nether wart is a plant found in the Nether.

The data pack system provides a way for players to further customize their Minecraft experience. Data packs can be used to override or add new advancements, functions, loot tables, predicates, structures, recipes and tags without any code modification.

A rabbit's foot is a brewing item obtained from rabbits.
Pufferfish are uncommon defensive mobs found in oceans.

Armor[a] is a category of items that provide players and certain mobs with varying levels of protection from common damage types, and appear graphically on the wearer. These items include several different tiers of helmets, chestplates, leggings, and boots, which can each be placed in designated armor slots of a player's inventory for use.

A tool  is an item used by the player while held to perform actions faster and more efficiently, to gather materials not obtainable by hand, to gain information, or to perform completely new actions. With the exception of the clock, compass and bucket (when empty), tools do not stack in the inventory. Tools can be repaired; see Item Repair.
Weapons are tools and items that can be used to damage entities. There are currently 10 weapons in-game :
An enchanting table[a] is a block that allows players to spend their experience point levels to enchant tools, weapons, books, and armor.

Experience (EXP or XP for short) can be obtained by gathering experience orbs from mining, defeating mobs and players, breeding, trading, fishing, completing advancements, and using grindstones and furnaces.
Lapis lazuli is a mineral used for enchanting and decoration.
An anvil is a block that allows players to repair items, rename items, and combine enchantments.
An enchanted book is an item that lets players add enchantments to certain items using an anvil.

Villagers are passive mobs that inhabit villages, work at their professions, breed, and interact. Their outfit varies according to their occupation and biome. A player can trade with villagers, using emeralds as currency.
Fishing is the process of using a fishing rod to obtain items, usually fish.
Zombies are common undead hostile mobs that attack players and villagers and burn in the daylight.
Drowned are common underwater zombie variants that spawn in bodies of water or when a zombie drowns. They are also the only source of tridents.
Husks are variants of zombies that spawn in deserts. Unlike zombies, husks do not burn in sunlight.
Skeletons are common undead hostile mobs equipped with bows. Around 2.5% of Skeletons are equipped with Enchanted Bows.
Strays are variants of skeletons that spawn only in frozen, ice, or snowy biomes.
Wither skeletons are hostile mobs with stone swords found in fortresses.
Zombie pigmen or zombified piglins‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16.0] are undead neutral mobs that mainly inhabit the Nether.
End cities are castle structures found on the outer islands of the End. They are inhabited by shulkers and hold among the most valuable loot in the game.
Shipwrecks are generated structures found in aqueous landscapes.
Mineshafts are generated structures that generate underground in the Overworld.
Dungeons are structures that appear in the Overworld.
Desert pyramids are pyramid-shaped sandstone structures naturally generated in deserts. Each pyramid contains valuable loot protected by a TNT trap.
Jungle temples‌[BE  only] or jungle pyramids‌[JE  only] are structures found in jungles.

Woodland mansions are large, rare structures found only in Dark Forest and Dark Forest Hills biomes. They are one of the only places where illagers spawn naturally (the others being patrols, raids, and pillager outposts) or where a totem of undying can be obtained (from evokers, who drop them, also spawn in raids).

Ocean ruins or underwater ruins are oceanic structures primarily composed of stone bricks or sandstone. They come in many different sizes varying from large villages to single ruined huts. They are rare, and have cold and warm variants.
Strongholds are structures that occur naturally underground, and are the only place where end portals can be found. Strongholds can be easily located by using an Eye of Ender.
A pillager is an illager[1] equipped with a crossbow. It spawns as part of illager patrols and around outposts.
Vindicators are illagers equipped with iron axes.
A raid is an in-game event in which waves of various mobs, mainly illagers, spawn and attack a village. It is triggered when a player with the Bad Omen status effect enters a village.
Gameplay in most game modes of Minecraft consists mainly of adding and destroying a variety of different blocks in a randomly generated world.
Commands are advanced features activated by typing certain strings of text.

Creative mode is one of the main game modes in Minecraft. Creative mode strips away the survival aspects of Minecraft and allows players to easily create and destroy structures and mechanisms. It also changes the background music.
This article is about the mechanics of enchanting.
Bookshelves are blocks that primarily serve to enhance enchanting with an enchantment table.
Air is the block present in otherwise empty space that has no transparent blocks and non-transparent blocks other than the air "block" itself.
Infinity is an enchantment to bows that prevents regular arrows from being consumed when shot. 1 arrow is needed to start.
Thorns is an armor enchantment that causes attackers to be damaged when they deal damage to the wearer.
Unbreaking is an enchantment that gives a chance for an item's durability not to be reduced when it is used, effectively increasing the item's durability.
no description
Knockback is an enchantment to a sword that increases the sword's knockback.
Mending is an enchantment which restores durability of an item using Experience Orbs.
An axe is a tool used to hasten the collection of wood-based items. It is also used as a weapon for melee attacks.

Pickaxes are one of the most commonly used tools in the game, being required to mine all ores, rock, rock-based blocks and metal-based blocks. They allow the player to mine blocks at faster speeds, and the speed increases depending on the material it is made out of.
Shovels are tools used to ease the process of collecting dirt and other blocks.
A grindstone is a weaponsmith's job site block, used to repair items and tools, or remove enchantments from them.
Aqua Affinity is a helmet enchantment that increases underwater mining rate.
Bane of Arthropods is a weapon enchantment that increases damage to "arthropod" mobs (spiders, cave spiders, bees, silverfish, and endermites).
Smite is an enchantment applied to a sword or axe, increasing the damage dealt to undead mobs.
Sharpness is an enchantment applied to a sword or axe that increases melee damage.
Blast Protection is an armor enchantment that reduces explosion damage.
Channeling is a trident enchantment that produces lightning.
Riptide is an enchantment to a trident, allowing the player to use the trident as a means of fast transportation.
Chopping is an enchantment to an axe that increases the axe's damage and shield disabling.
Curse of Binding is an enchantment that prevents removal of the cursed item from its armor slot.
Curse of Vanishing is an enchantment that causes the item to disappear on death.
Depth Strider is an armor enchantment that increases underwater movement speed.
Frost Walker is an enchantment to boots that creates frosted ice blocks when walking over water.
Efficiency is an enchantment that increases the player's mining speed.
Feather Falling is an enchantment to boots that reduces fall damage. It does not affect falling speed.
Fire Aspect is a sword enchantment that sets the target on fire.
Fire Protection is an armor enchantment that reduces damage from fire.
Flame is an enchantment that causes bows to shoot flaming arrows.
Fortune is an enchantment applied to mining and digging tools that increases the amount and/or chances of specific item drops. It does not increase experience drops.
Silk Touch is an enchantment that allows many blocks to drop themselves instead of their usual items when mined. It additionally can be used as a preventative measure to not displease bees.
Frosted ice is a translucent solid block.
Impaling is an enchantment for a trident, causing the trident to deal extra damage on each hit.
Looting is an enchantment for swords that can cause mobs to drop more items (does not affect XP).
Loyalty is an enchantment to a thrown trident, causing it to return to the player.
Luck of the Sea is an enchantment to a fishing rod that increases luck while fishing.
Lure is an enchantment to a fishing rod which decreases the wait time for catching fish.
Multishot is an enchantment applied to a crossbow.
Piercing is an enchantment applied to a crossbow.
Power is a bow enchantment which increases arrow damage.
Projectile Protection is an armor enchantment that reduces damage from projectiles.
Protection is an enchantment applied to armor that increases the armor's damage reduction.
Punch is an enchantment for a bow that increases an arrow's knockback, like sword's knockback enchantment.
Quick Charge is an enchantment for quickly reloading a crossbow.
Respiration is a helmet enchantment for extending breathing time underwater. If applied to other armor pieces using commands, the effect still takes place.

Bedrock Edition (also known as the Bedrock Version or just Bedrock) refers to the multi-platform family of editions of Minecraft developed by Mojang AB, Xbox Game Studios, 4J Studios, and SkyBox Labs. Prior to this term, as the engine originated with Pocket Edition, this entire product family was referred to as "Pocket Edition", "MCPE", or "Pocket/Windows 10 Edition".
Soul Speed is an enchantment that can be applied on boots and allows the player to walk quicker on soul sand.
Soul sand is a block found naturally only in the Nether. Soul sand slows down the movement of mobs and players standing on it. It is also used for growing nether wart and for constructing a Wither.
Soul soil is a block naturally found only in the soul sand valley.
Sweeping Edge is a sword enchantment that increases sweep attack damage.

Minecraft: Java Edition (previously known as Minecraft) is the original version of Minecraft, developed by Mojang AB for Windows, macOS, and Linux. Notch began development on May 10, 2009, publicly releasing Minecraft on May 17, 2009. The full release of the game was on November 18, 2011, at MINECON 2011.

Enchanting is a mechanic that augments armor, tools, weapons, and books with one or more of a variety of "enchantments" that improve an item's existing abilities or imbue them with additional abilities and uses.

Multiplayer is the server-based version of Minecraft that enables multiple players to interact with each other on a single world, allowing them to work together to mine ores, build structures, and fight mobs (or each other).
Gold or golden may refer to:
A sword is a melee weapon that is mainly used to deal damage to mobs and/or players. Swords are also useful for mining cobwebs.

Mobs are "living", moving game entities. The term "mob" is short for "mobile".[1]
Mobs also can be attacked and hurt (from falling, burning, attacked by player or mob, falling into the void, etc) and some of them can be drowned. Mobs like cod, salmon, tropical fish, pufferfish, drowned, guardian, elder guardian can't be drowned, mobs also have a different AI for some mobs. And when killed, some mobs can drop a different loots.

Breaking, digging, punching, or mining is a common activity in Minecraft, performed (by default) by holding the left mouse button while the cursor is pointing at a block. Breaking is used to create passages, tunnels and clear away unwanted blocks, and is the primary way of acquiring blocks for future placement or crafting.
A furnace is a storage block used to smelt blocks and items, converting them into other blocks or items.

A tool  is an item used by the player while held to perform actions faster and more efficiently, to gather materials not obtainable by hand, to gain information, or to perform completely new actions. With the exception of the clock, compass and bucket (when empty), tools do not stack in the inventory. Tools can be repaired; see Item Repair.
Hoes are tools used to till dirt and grass blocks into farmland, as well as quickly harvest certain blocks.‌[upcoming: JE 1.16]

The Mojang Bug Tracker (also known as Mojira) is the official website location for players to report bugs for Minecraft. Similar to the feedback site, it is community moderated. The bug tracker is located at bugs.mojang.com.

Helmets are a type of armor that covers the head of the player. There are seven types of helmets: leather cap, chainmail helmet, iron helmet, diamond helmet, gold helmet, netherite helmet‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16], and turtle shell.
Chestplates are a type of armor that covers the upper body of the player. There are six types of chestplates: leather, chainmail, iron, diamond, gold and netherite‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].

Leggings are a type of armor that covers the lower body of the player. There are six types of leggings: leather pants, chain leggings, iron leggings, diamond leggings, gold leggings and netherite leggings‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].

Boots are a type of armor that covers the feet of the player. There are six types of boots: leather boots, chainmail boots, iron boots, diamond boots, gold boots and netherite boots‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16].
A pumpkin is a fruit block that appears in patches of grassy biomes. Pumpkins have the same texture on all 4 sides.
Heads are decorative blocks. There are six types of heads: player, zombie, skeleton, wither skeleton, creeper, and dragon.
A warped fungus on a stick is an item that can be used to control saddled striders.
Cod are common passive fish mobs found in oceans.
Salmon are common passive mobs found in oceans and rivers.
Tropical Fish are common passive mobs found in oceans. There are 3,584 possible variants.
Guardians are pufferfish-like hostile mobs found in ocean monuments.
The elder guardian is a stronger, larger variant of the guardian that can inflict Mining Fatigue.
Drops are items that appear when mobs and some other entities die or when most kinds of blocks are broken.
Spawning refers to players and mobs being created and placed in the game world.
Light (or lighting) in Minecraft affects visibility, mob spawning, and plant growth. There are two types of light: sky light, which is provided by the sun, and block light.

Biomes are regions in a world with varying geographical features, flora, heights, temperatures, humidity ratings, and sky and foliage colors. Biomes separate every generated world into different environments, such as forests, jungles, deserts, and taigas.
Breeding is a game mechanic that allows mobs of the same species to breed with each other in order to produce offspring.
Opacity (and its inverse, transparency) are properties of blocks with a wide range of effects on the game world.
A snow golem is a snowman-like utility mob that helps defend against hostile mobs.
The wither is an undead boss mob that floats and shoots explosive skulls at its enemies and is currently the only directly player-made hostile mob in the game.
Iron golems are large, strong utility mobs that defend players and villagers.
A spawn egg[a] is an item used to spawn mobs directly.
The ender dragon is a dangerous, flying boss mob found when first entering the End. It is also the largest mob naturally spawning in the game.

The Named Binary Tag (NBT) format is used by Minecraft for the various files in which it saves data. The format is described by Notch in a very brief specification.[1] The format is designed to store data in a tree structure made up of various tags. All tags have an ID and a name. The original known version was 19132 as introduced in Beta 1.3, and since then has been updated to 19133 with the Anvil file format, whichs adds the Int Array tag. The NBT format dates all the way back to Indev with tags 0 to 10 in use.
Physics may refer to:
Damage represents injury from attacks or natural causes.
Ladders are wooden blocks used for climbing walls either vertically or horizontally. They can be placed only on the sides of other blocks.
Particles are special graphical effects in Minecraft that are created when certain events occur, such as explosions, rainfall, or smelting items in a furnace.
Drops are items that appear when mobs and some other entities die or when most kinds of blocks are broken.

Mobs are "living", moving game entities. The term "mob" is short for "mobile".[1]
Mobs also can be attacked and hurt (from falling, burning, attacked by player or mob, falling into the void, etc) and some of them can be drowned. Mobs like cod, salmon, tropical fish, pufferfish, drowned, guardian, elder guardian can't be drowned, mobs also have a different AI for some mobs. And when killed, some mobs can drop a different loots.
Rails are non-solid blocks that provide a path along which minecarts can travel.
Bats are ambient[1] flying passive mobs that spawn in caves.
Cats are tameable passive mobs found in villages.
A chicken is a common passive mob found in grassy biomes.
A cow is a common passive mob found in the Overworld. They are a source of leather, raw beef and milk.
A donkey is a mob that can be ridden when tamed.
Foxes are nocturnal passive mobs that spawn commonly in taiga, giant tree taiga, and snowy taiga biomes. They move to villages during the night.
Horses are passive mobs that can be ridden when tamed.
Mooshrooms are mushroom-covered variants of cows exclusive to the mushroom fields biome.
A mule is a tameable mob that can be ridden when tamed.
Ocelots are rare passive mobs found in jungles.
Parrots are rare tameable mobs found in jungles. Parrots can imitate sounds of nearby hostile mobs and can perch on the player's shoulders.
Pigs are common passive mobs that spawn in the Overworld. They drop porkchops upon death, and can be ridden with saddles.
Rabbits are rare passive mobs. They are a source of rabbit's foot and rabbit hide, as well as meat.
A turtle is a common passive mob that moves both on land and in water.
Sheep are passive mobs found in grassy biomes that supply wool and mutton.
Skeleton horses are undead variants of regular horses.
A snow golem is a snowman-like utility mob that helps defend against hostile mobs.
Squid are eight-armed passive mobs that spawn in water.
The wandering trader is a passive mob found randomly across the world. It can trade, making natural items more available and in some cases, less dangerous to obtain.
A turtle is a common passive mob that moves both on land and in water.

Status effects are various conditions, which can be either helpful or harmful, that affect an entity. They can be inflicted in various ways throughout the game, including consuming potions and some food items, being in the range of beacons and conduits, and being attacked by or close to certain mobs.
Bees are neutral mobs that live in bee nests and beehives. If provoked, bees attack in a swarm to sting the player and inflict poison.
Cave spiders are small, venomous variants of spiders that live in abandoned mineshafts.
Dolphins are neutral mobs  that live in non-frozen oceans.
Endermen are tall, black neutral mobs from the End that have the ability to teleport, and pick up blocks.
Iron golems are large, strong utility mobs that defend players and villagers.
Llamas are neutral mobs that can be tamed and used to transport large shipments of items.
A panda is a rare passive mob that resides in jungles.
Polar bears are neutral mobs that live in icy biomes.
Spiders are common neutral mobs that have the unique ability to climb walls.
Wolves are neutral mobs that can be tamed.
Zombie pigmen or zombified piglins‌[upcoming: JE 1.16 & BE 1.16.0] are undead neutral mobs that mainly inhabit the Nether.

Creepers are common green, deadly hostile mobs that silently approach players and explode shortly after coming within 3 blocks of their targets. Due to their distinctive appearance and high potential for killing unwary players as well as damaging the environment and players' constructions, creepers have become one of the icons of Minecraft, notorious both among players and non-players.
The elder guardian is a stronger, larger variant of the guardian that can inflict Mining Fatigue.
Endermites are the smallest hostile mobs in Minecraft.
An evoker is a spell-casting illager found in woodland mansions and raids, and is the only source of the totem of undying.

Ghasts are floating hostile mobs that live in the Nether and shoot explosive fireballs at the player. They are the second-largest mobs that naturally spawn in the game, the largest being the ender dragon. The real second-largest mobs are actually the Giants, but can only be summoned with Commands, so they do not count.

A magma cube is a hostile mob whose skin is dark red and black with red, orange, and yellow eyes. It is found in big, small and tiny sizes, exclusively in the Nether. They are considered the Nether equivalent of slimes, with similar behaviors.
Phantoms are undead hostile mobs that spawn when the player has not slept in over three in-game days.
Ravagers are large hostile mobs that spawn in raids and attack players, villagers, wandering traders and iron golems.
Shulkers are box-shaped hostile mobs found in end cities. They hide in their shell to blend in with surrounding purpur blocks and guard the city's various treasures.
Silverfish are small, bug-like hostile mobs found in strongholds and mountains.
Skeleton horses are undead variants of regular horses.
Slimes are bouncy cube-shaped hostile mobs that spawn in the swamp and, occasionally, deep underground. Also in slime chunks.
A spider jockey[1] is the rare appearance of a spider or cave spider‌[BE  only] being ridden by a skeleton, stray, or wither skeleton.
Vexes are flying hostile mobs summoned in small groups by the spell-casting evoker.

Witches are uncommon hostile mobs that use harmful splash potions as ranged weapons and beneficial potions on themselves defensively. While dangerous, they are a source of valuable potion ingredients.
Wither skeletons are hostile mobs with stone swords found in fortresses.
Zombie villagers are variants of zombies that can be cured into normal villagers using golden apples and weakness potions.
The ender dragon is a dangerous, flying boss mob found when first entering the End. It is also the largest mob naturally spawning in the game.

Blocking is a gameplay mechanic that allows players to block several forms of damage.
Sand is a block affected by gravity.
Sandstone is a solid block commonly found in deserts and beaches underneath sand. Red sandstone is a related block, associated with red sand.
Slabs are half-versions of their respective blocks.

Vines are non-solid blocks, 1⁄16 of a block in thickness that can be placed only against a vertical side of a solid block. They also can be supported by a solid block ceilings if adjacent to a solid vertical wall.
Snow[a] is a ground cover block that is commonly caused by snowfall.
A turtle egg[a] is a block that hatches one or more baby turtles.
Sea pickles are light-emitting colonies of small stationary animals found underwater.

Liquids (or fluids) are a special type of block that can cause "liquid" to flow over the terrain forming rivers, or falls. Currently the two blocks of this type in the main versions of Minecraft are water and lava.
Dirt is a block found abundantly in most biomes under a layer of grass blocks at the top of the Overworld.
Sandstone is a solid block commonly found in deserts and beaches underneath sand. Red sandstone is a related block, associated with red sand.
Glass is a decorative, fully transparent solid block that can be dyed into stained glass.
A flower is a naturally occurring plant that occurs in a variety of shapes and colors.

An explosion is a physical event, generally destructive, that can be caused by several different circumstances. It can destroy nearby blocks, propel and damage nearby players, entities, and their armor, and cause one or more fires under correct circumstances. Explosions produce a "shockwave" particle effect.
Torches are non-solid blocks that emit light.
Glowstone is a light-emitting block that appears in the Nether, and that can be acquired from trading.
Sand is a block affected by gravity.
Gravel is a block that is affected by gravity.
The dragon egg is a decorative block or a "trophy item", and the rarest item in the game.
Concrete powder is a solid block that comes in the 16 regular dye colors. Like sand, gravel, anvils, and the dragon egg, concrete powder obeys the law of gravity.
Scaffolding is a block used when building structures to help the player reach higher places, or to descend safely without taking fall damage.
Sound may refer to:
Particles are special graphical effects in Minecraft that are created when certain events occur, such as explosions, rainfall, or smelting items in a furnace.
A piston is a block capable of pushing movable blocks and players when given a redstone pulse.
A powered rail is a type of rail that is used to decrease or increase the velocity of moving minecarts.
A detector rail is a block that can transport minecarts and can be used as a switchable redstone power source.
An activator rail is a type of rail that can "activate" certain minecarts.
Redstone dust[a] is a mineral that can transmit redstone power when placed as a block.
A redstone comparator is a block used in redstone circuits to maintain, compare, or subtract signal strength, or to measure certain block states (primarily the fullness of containers).
A redstone repeater is a block used in redstone circuits to "repeat" redstone signals back to full strength, delay signals, prevent signals moving backwards, or to "lock" signals in one state.
Leaves are blocks that grow as part of trees. Leaves mainly drop saplings and sticks.
Stairs are blocks that allow mobs and players to change elevation without jumping.
Lava is a light-emitting fluid block that causes fire damage, which generates below y-level 10 in the Overworld and below y-level 31 in the Nether.
The nether portal block is the translucent part of the nether portal that teleports the player to and from the Nether.
The end portal block is a block generated when an end portal or exit portal is activated, which teleports the player between the Overworld and the End.
The end gateway is a block that appears as part of end gateways, which teleport the player between the main island and the other islands in the End.
Prismarine is a blue stone that appears underwater in ruins and ocean monuments.
Sea lanterns are underwater light sources that appear in ocean monuments and underwater ruins.
A magma block is a light-emitting naturally-occurring block found in the Nether and the Overworld. It causes fire damage when stepped on.
Seagrass is a non-solid plant block that generates in all oceans, except frozen oceans.
Kelp is an underwater plant that generates in most oceans.
Fire is a harmful non-solid block that can spread to nearby flammable blocks.
Lanterns are blocks that emit light.
A blast furnace is a block that smelts ores and metal armor and tools, similar to a furnace. It also serves as an armorer's job site block.
A smoker is a block that cooks food items, similar to a furnace, but faster. It also serves as a butcher's job site block.
The stonecutter can be used to craft stone-related blocks in smaller and more precise quantities than crafting. It also serves as a stone mason's job site block.
A command block is a block that can execute commands. Because it cannot be obtained in Survival mode without cheats, it is primarily used on multiplayer servers and in custom maps.
A button is a non-solid block that can provide temporary redstone power.
A door is a block that can be used as a barrier that can be opened by hand or with redstone.
Fences are wall blocks that cannot normally be jumped over.
A fence gate is a block that shares the functions of both the door and the fence.

Cobblestone is a common block, obtained from mining stone. Its texture resembles block of stone with a largely cracked surface.

Minecraft servers allow players to play online or via a local area network with other people. Internally, the game runs a server for single-player games, this was done in order to make the single-player game experience consistent with the multi-player experience and make it so that changes made to the game such as bug fixes apply to both single-player games and multi-player games. Official server software is only available on Java Edition in the release state. Bedrock Edition server software is currently in Alpha.

A grass block is a natural block that generates abundantly across the surface of the Overworld.

Liquids (or fluids) are a special type of block that can cause "liquid" to flow over the terrain forming rivers, or falls. Currently the two blocks of this type in the main versions of Minecraft are water and lava.
Damage represents injury from attacks or natural causes.
Wheat seeds[a] are items used in farming.
Signs are non-solid blocks that can display text.
Redstone ore is the ore block from which redstone is obtained.
A redstone torch is a non-solid block that can be used as a toggleable redstone power source, as well as a signal inverter.
Sugar cane is a block found as 1–4-block-tall plants near water in the Overworld. As an item, it is an important crafting ingredient.
A redstone repeater is a block used in redstone circuits to "repeat" redstone signals back to full strength, delay signals, prevent signals moving backwards, or to "lock" signals in one state.
A redstone lamp is a block that produces light when activated with a redstone signal.
A redstone comparator is a block used in redstone circuits to maintain, compare, or subtract signal strength, or to measure certain block states (primarily the fullness of containers).
The resource pack system is an API which provides a way for players to customize textures, models, music, sounds, languages, the end poem, splashes, and fonts, without any code modification.
Portal may refer to:
An end portal is a naturally occurring generated structure that is used to travel into The End. It can only be found in the portal room of a stronghold.
Superflat (Flat in Bedrock Edition) is a world type replacing the normal varied terrain of the Overworld, with customizable layers in Java Edition.

Since the beginning of the development of Pocket Edition and Bedrock Edition, there have been a number of features that were removed from the game. These features may have been replaced, or a developer decided against the feature later on.

Invisible bedrock is an indestructible, solid block, similar to bedrock and has the appearance of air. Although it is invisible, it technically uses the stone texture, as seen in its inventory icon.
It shares many of its properties with barriers.

The nether reactor core is a block exclusive to Bedrock Edition, New Nintendo 3DS Edition, Pi Edition, and Education Edition which cannot be crafted and can only be obtained by using an inventory editor plus addons/mods.
Glowing obsidian is a Bedrock Edition exclusive block that has no use, other than decorating.

Chế độ sinh tồn là một trong những cách chơi|chế độ trong Minecraft. Người chơi phải thu thập tài nguyên, xây dựng các cấu trúc, chiến đấu với các sinh vật, ăn uống, và khám phá thế giới để phát triển và sinh tồn.

Ores are uncommon rock-type blocks used to obtain specific resources.

This page lists generated structures in Minecraft. A generated structure is defined as any structure that is disabled when the "Generate structures" world creation option is turned off. Some structures such as dungeons and desert wells do still generate with this option turned off but are listed on this page due to them having the appearance of a artificial structure as opposed to a natural formation.

Border blocks are unbreakable blocks that prohibit movement through, over or under them. They are exclusive to Education Edition.[until BE 1.16.0][1]
Allow and deny blocks can be used to create restricted building areas or areas where users can build. They are exclusive to the Education Edition.[until 1.16.0][1]

A chalkboard is an Education Edition exclusive block that can display more text than a sign.[1] Three sizes are available - 1×1 (slate), 2×1 (poster), and 2×3 (board).

Underwater torches are non-solid blocks that emit light underwater.
The lab table is a block used in chemistry to design one's own experiments by combining substances and observing the results.
The material reducer is a block used in chemistry to learn about the natural world, by reducing Minecraft blocks to their component elements.
The element constructor is a block used in chemistry. It allows the construction of elements by adjusting the number of protons, electrons and neutrons.
The compound creator is a block used in chemistry. It allows over thirty compounds to be created by combining elements. This includes certain items which are available in the game normally.
Underwater TNT is a block that can be used by the player to initiate a controlled explosion underwater.
Colored torches are torches colored by chloride, available in blue, red, purple, and green.
